awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Innovative High Throughput Automated System for Individualized Poultry Vaccination and Recognition and Removal of Unhealthy Chicks
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project has the potential to help enhance disease resistance in poultry and increase yields due to the delivery of only healthy, fully vaccinated chicks to farms. These healthier chicks will reduce the need for antibiotics in poultry, aiding to combat antimicrobial resistance.  This technology has immediate applications in other food animal industries and fisheries, and allows for data capture on numbers of animals and types of treatments given. Broader applications would include any image capture and analysis that relies on analytics to identify target areas for delivery of substances to live animals or humans.


This SBIR Phase II project will allow for the advancement and commercialization of imaging technologies for the use of screening and targeting live animals. This proposal brings innovation in the care of food animals allowing for producers to move away from flock health and focus on the care of individual animals. This will be a dramatic change for the poultry industry, but is necessary in the face of antibiotic removal to be able to improve the current vaccination efficiencies and screen chicks for health status. Individualized care is currently not possible due to the high throughput needed to keep pace with large scale commercial hatchery operation. The technical challenges this proposal will overcome include 1) the safe and effective handling of chicks in an automated system that can process 100,000 chicks per hour, 2) the development of imaging systems for health checks and target recognition, 3) the delivery of the appropriate dose of vaccine with the correct amount of agents (virus, bacteria, parasite, and other agents) while not damaging the agents during delivery, and 4) development of a system that is rugged and robust enough to survive in a hatchery environment.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
SBIR Phase II & IIB Project Titled: Innovative High Throughput Automated System for Individualized Poultry Vaccination and Recognition and Removal of Unhealthy Chicks. 

Our company is focused on developing solutions for the animal health industry.  With this project, we focused on developing and commercializing a system that could individually vaccinate chickens at the rates needed for large-scale broiler chicken hatcheries.  Many hatcheries are processing over 1 million chicks per week at rates of 100,000 chicks per hour.  This results in the mass application of vaccines on the day of the hatch to keep up with the needed throughput.  Mass application of vaccines results in many unvaccinated or partially vaccinated chicks being delivered to farms.  Our system would ensure over 95% of chicks receive a full dose of vaccine before delivery to the farm.

During our Phase II and IIB NSF SBIR, we developed a four-lane prototype system that could transport, singulate, image, and vaccinate day-of-age chicks individually.  With the four-lane prototype, we proved the system could humanly transport chicks, capture images of chicks, and vaccinate chicks at rates up to 50,000 chicks per hour.  We would use two four-lane systems to accomplish the needed rate of 100,000 chicks per hour.  The four-lane prototype has successfully vaccinated chicks with cocci vaccinates over 90% of chicks with E. maxima species of cocci, while transitional spray cabinet vaccination rates are typically under 50%.  To be considered vaccinated, we are looking for the presence of the parasite in the intestines of vaccinated chicks on day 7.   Our Phase IIB project focused on the development of a commercially viable product.  We focused our efforts on making the chick movement and singulation, vaccine handling, high-speed vision and targeting, and chick counting and boxing subsystems more robust.  We successfully delivered individual birds to the vision system, allowing for the detection of the chick orientation and key features to target the facial features.  The vaccine handling system ensures the vaccine delivered is uniform, improving vaccine take.   The chick counting and boxing system are essential to ensure the humane handling of the chicks as well as the delivery of accurate numbers of chicks to the farms.  

 


Last Modified: 11/10/2022
Modified by: Ramin Karimpour

por.por_txt_cntn:
SBIR Phase II & IIB Project Titled: Innovative High Throughput Automated System for Individualized Poultry Vaccination and Recognition and Removal of Unhealthy Chicks. 

Our company is focused on developing solutions for the animal health industry.  With this project, we focused on developing and commercializing a system that could individually vaccinate chickens at the rates needed for large-scale broiler chicken hatcheries.  Many hatcheries are processing over 1 million chicks per week at rates of 100,000 chicks per hour.  This results in the mass application of vaccines on the day of the hatch to keep up with the needed throughput.  Mass application of vaccines results in many unvaccinated or partially vaccinated chicks being delivered to farms.  Our system would ensure over 95% of chicks receive a full dose of vaccine before delivery to the farm.

During our Phase II and IIB NSF SBIR, we developed a four-lane prototype system that could transport, singulate, image, and vaccinate day-of-age chicks individually.  With the four-lane prototype, we proved the system could humanly transport chicks, capture images of chicks, and vaccinate chicks at rates up to 50,000 chicks per hour.  We would use two four-lane systems to accomplish the needed rate of 100,000 chicks per hour.  The four-lane prototype has successfully vaccinated chicks with cocci vaccinates over 90% of chicks with E. maxima species of cocci, while transitional spray cabinet vaccination rates are typically under 50%.  To be considered vaccinated, we are looking for the presence of the parasite in the intestines of vaccinated chicks on day 7.   Our Phase IIB project focused on the development of a commercially viable product.  We focused our efforts on making the chick movement and singulation, vaccine handling, high-speed vision and targeting, and chick counting and boxing subsystems more robust.  We successfully delivered individual birds to the vision system, allowing for the detection of the chick orientation and key features to target the facial features.  The vaccine handling system ensures the vaccine delivered is uniform, improving vaccine take.   The chick counting and boxing system are essential to ensure the humane handling of the chicks as well as the delivery of accurate numbers of chicks to the farms.
